questions.text: Not a risk factor for venous thromboembolism:
questions.solution:
Venous thromboembolism: risk factors

EXPLANATION:

Option A. Male gender: Correct. Being male is not considered a specific risk factor for venous thromboembolism (VTE).

Option B. Varicose veins: Incorrect. Varicose veins are a risk factor for developing VTE due to venous stasis.

Option C. Infection: Incorrect. Infections can trigger systemic inflammation, increasing the risk of VTE.

Option D. Heart failure: Incorrect. Heart failure reduces venous return, increasing the risk of clot formation.

Key points :

  • Risk factors for VTE include varicose veins, infection, and heart failure. Male gender is not a significant risk factor on its own.

questions.text: A 45 years old male patient presents to the hospital with asymptomatic varicose veins, whose image is given below. Which CEAP classification does the patient fall under?
questions.solution:
CEAP classification of chronic lower extremity venous disease

  • The descriptive CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classificationfor chronic venous disorders is widely utilised.

For clinical classification:

  • C0: no signs of venous disease;
  • C1: telangiectasia or reticular veins;
  • C2: varicose veins;
  • C3: oedema;
  • C4a: pigmentation or eczema;
  • C4b: LDS or atrophie blanche;
  • C4c Corona phlebectatica
  • C5: healed venous ulcer;
  • C6: active venous ulcer.

Clinical class can be further characterised as symptomatic (s), asymptomatic (a) or recurrent following previous successful treatment or healing (r), e.g. C2a, C2s, C6r.

For aetiological classification:

  • Ec: congenital;
  • Ep: primary;
  • Es: secondary (post-thrombotic);
  • En: no venous cause identified.

For anatomical classification:

  • As: superficial veins;
  • Ap: perforator veins;
  • Ad: deep veins;
  • An: no venous location identified.

For pathophysiological classification:

  • Pr: reflux;
  • Po: obstruction;
  • Pr,o: reflux and obstruction;
  • Pn: no venous pathophysiology identifiable.

Option A. C6: Correct. C6 indicates active venous ulcers.

Option B. C5: Incorrect. C5 refers to healed venous ulcers.

Option C. C4b: Incorrect. LDS or atrophie blanch.

Option D. C4a: Incorrect. pigmentation or eczema.

Key points: According to the CEAP classification, asymptomatic varicose veins fall under C2.

questions.text: 75 year male with known case of DM-2, patient presented to emergency with claudication of calf muscles, numbness in thigh with impotence. Image showing gangrene of foot is given below. Which artery is involved?
questions.solution:
• Aortic-iliac bifurcation emboli
    • History of claudication pain will be absent.
    • may have a history of atrial fibrillation.
    • Sudden onset acute limb ischemia will occur.

Explanation:

Option A. Aortic-iliac bifurcation thrombus: Correct. Atherosclerotic disease affecting the aortic bifurcation (also known as Leriche syndrome) presents with classic symptoms such as claudication in the calf and thigh, impotence, and diminished pulses.

Option B. Internal iliac artery: Incorrect. The internal iliac artery supplies the pelvis, and involvement typically causes gluteal or hip claudication but would not commonly present with symptoms in the thigh or cause impotence.

Option C. Bilateral popliteal artery: Incorrect. While involvement of the popliteal arteries can cause lower extremity ischemia, this would typically not lead to thigh symptoms or impotence, which are more indicative of proximal (aortic or iliac) involvement.

Option D. Aortic-iliac bifurcation emboli: Incorrect. Emboli at the aortic bifurcation would present with acute symptoms such as sudden onset of pain and limb ischemia rather than the chronic course seen with claudication and gradual ischemia as in thrombotic occlusion

Key points:

  • Aortic-iliac bifurcation thrombus (Leriche syndrome) is the most likely cause in this case. Symptoms include claudication, impotence, and reduced pulses in the legs. Chronic ischemia from the thrombus leads to gangrene if untreated.

questions.text: 88 year female known case of hypertension presented with hypotension and differential BP on both sides with following CT angiography findings. What could be the cause ?
questions.solution:
Aortic Dissection

This occurs when a defect or gap occurs in the intima of the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into the aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer and creating a false lumen. It most commonly occurs in the ascending aorta or, less often, just distal to the left subclavian artery. It is also more common in men, typically those aged 50-70 years, and in Afro-Caribbean patients.

Predisposing factors for aortic dissection

  • Age
  • Hypertension
  • Marfan syndrome
  • Pregnancy
  • Other connective tissue disorders, e.g. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, giant cell arteritis, systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Turner or Noonan syndromes
  • Aortic cannulation site following previous cardiac surgery (iatrogenic)

Clinical features

The presentation is often with tearing interscapular pain not unlike the pain of myocardial ischaemia, and it may be difficult to distinguish between the two. The extent of arterial dissection may produce widespread symptoms and signs.

The dissection can extend distally down the aorta and spiral to involve:

  • The renal arteries (renal pain and renal failure);
  • The mesenteric arteries (abdominal pain and bowel ischaemia);
  • The spinal arteries (paraplegia);
  • The iliac arteries (leg pain, pallor, loss of or reduced pulses and acute limb ischaemia).

The dissection may track proximally to involve:

  • The head and neck vessels (symptoms and signs of a stroke or transient ischaemic attack);
  • The coronary vessels (MI);
  • The aortic root (aortic regurgitation).

The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left haemothorax).

  • Interarm systolic BP differential is a classic sign of acute aortic dissection (AAD).All previous studies looking at the association of BP differential with AAD combine systolic BP differential >20 mm Hg with pulse deficit.

Explanation:

Option A. Aortic Dissection:

Correct. Aortic dissection presents with hypotension, differential blood pressure between arms, and characteristic findings on CT angiography. It occurs due to a tear in the intimal layer of the aorta, causing blood to flow between the layers, leading to a false lumen.

Option B. Acute coronary syndrome:

Incorrect. While hypotension can be present, differential BP is not a hallmark of acute coronary syndrome.

Option C. Pulmonary artery hypertension:

Incorrect. Pulmonary hypertension usually presents with signs of right heart strain and does not cause differential blood pressure between limbs or the typical CT findings of aortic dissection.

Option D. Thromboembolism:

Incorrect. A thromboembolism could lead to ischemia and hypotension, but it would not explain the differential BP between the arms or the CT findings specific to an aortic dissection.

Key points :

Aortic dissection should be suspected in hypertensive patients presenting with differential blood pressure between the arms and hypotension. CT angiography is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: 90 year Vandanaben is diagnosed with triple vessel block, she is posted for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting. In preoperative work up Allen's test was performed. Which of the following conduits was planned to be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A :

  • The long saphenous vein is the most commonly used venous conduit as it is straightforward to harvest, provides good length and is easy to handle. Historical studies showed a limited long-term patency rate for long saphenous vein grafts (50-60% at 10 years). However, recent studies suggest that early postoperative use of lipid-lowering agents and antiplatelet agents such as low-dose aspirin can improve vein graft long-term patency.
  • The Saphenous nerve accompanies the GSV medially from the ankle to the level of the knee and supplies cutaneous sensation to the medial leg and ankle. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of GSV.

Option B :

  • Alternative vein conduits include the short saphenous vein or upper limb veins such as the cephalic vein; however, these grafts are associated with poorer long-term patency rates.
  • The sural nerve accompanies the SSV laterally along its course and supplies cutaneous sensation to the lateral malleolar region. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of SSV.

Option C :

  • The left internal mammary artery (LIMA), or internal thoracic artery, has become the conduit of choice for LAD grafting. Evidence from the mid-1980s to the present day suggests a 10-year patency rate of >95%, with a lower reoperation rate.

Option D :

  • The use of the radial artery as an alternative arterial bypass graft has undergone a recent revival. This has been driven by the belief that total arterial revascularization (avoiding venous conduits) might improve long-term results of coronary surgery.

When assessing a patient in whom a radial artery harvest is planned, an Allen's test should be performed. The alternative would be a vascular assessment of the radial and ulnar arteries with ultrasound.

Key points :

When assessing a patient in whom a radial artery harvest is planned, an Allen's test should be performed.

choices.text: USG monitoring till size of the aneurysm reaches 70 mm

questions.text: 45 years old Thomas presents to the hospital with abdominal pain and is incidentally detected with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. What would be wrong advice from below except?
questions.solution:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm

  • Abdominal aortic aneurysm is by far the most common type of large-vessel aneurysmand is found in 2% of the population at autopsy; 95% have associated atheromatous degeneration and 95% occur below the renal arteries.
  • Most remain asymptomatic until rupture occurs; the risk of rupture increases with increasing size (diameter) of the aneurysm.
  • Symptomatic aneurysms may cause minor symptoms, such as back and abdominal discomfort, before sudden, severe back and/or abdominal pain develops from expansion and rupture.
  • Rarely, symptoms may occur as a result of erosion or compression of surrounding structures, e.g. aortoenteric fistula or ureteric obstruction.

Asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm

  • An asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm in an otherwise fit patient should be considered for repair if >55 mm in diameter, measured by ultrasonography in the anteroposterior plane.

The annual incidence of rupture rises exponentially as the aneurysm size passes 55 mm:

  • ≤1% are in aneurysms that are <55 mm in diameter,
  • 5-10% are in those that are 55-60 mm in diameter
  • 25% are in those that are ≥70 mm in diameter.

Explanation:

Option A. Immediate surgery: Incorrect. Immediate surgery is not recommended unless the aneurysm is symptomatic or rapidly expanding. Elective surgery is typically considered when the aneurysm reaches a specific size threshold, usually around 55 mm

Option .B. USG monitoring till size of the aneurysm reaches 70 mm: Incorrect.

Option C. Monitor till size reaches 40 mm: Incorrect. Monitoring is appropriate for smaller aneurysms, but surgical intervention is usually considered when the aneurysm reaches 55 mm.

Option D. Monitor till size reaches 55 mm: Correct. Elective surgery is recommended when the aneurysm reaches 55 mm to prevent rupture, so this is the correct management strategy.

Key points :An asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm in an otherwise fit patient should be considered for repair if >55 mm in diameter, measured by ultrasonography in the anteroposterior plane.

choices.text: Monitor till size reaches 55 mm hg

questions.text: 45 years old Thomas presents to the hospital with abdominal pain and is incidentally detected with an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture. identify true statements regarding management ?
questions.solution:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm

Abdominal aortic aneurysm is by far the most common type of large-vessel aneurysm and is found in 2% of the population at autopsy; 95% have associated atheromatous degeneration and 95% occur below the renal arteries.

  • Most remain asymptomatic until rupture occurs; the risk of rupture increases with increasing size (diameter) of the aneurysm.
  • Symptomatic aneurysms may cause minor symptoms, such as back and abdominal discomfort, before sudden, severe back and/or abdominal pain develops from expansion and rupture.
  • Rarely, symptoms may occur as a result of erosion or compression of surrounding structures, e.g. aortoenteric fistula or ureteric obstruction.

Asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm

An asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm in an otherwise fit patient should be considered for repair if >55 mm in diameter, measured by ultrasonography in the anteroposterior plane.

The annual incidence of rupture rises exponentially as the aneurysm size passes 55 mm:

  • ≤1% are in aneurysms that are <55 mm in diameter,
  • 5-10% are in those that are 55-60 mm in diameter
  • 25% are in those that are ≥70 mm in diameter.

Symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm

  • These patients most commonly present with abdominal and/ or back pain but the aneurysm is not ruptured on CT scan.
  • Pain may also occur in the thigh and groin because of nerve compression.
  • The most common complications after open repair are
    • cardiac (ischaemia and infarction) and respiratory (atelectasis and lower lobe consolidation).
    • A degree of colonic ischaemia because of a lack of a collateral blood supply occurs in about 10% of patients, but this usually resolves spontaneously.
    • Acute kidney injury is an uncommon event after elective procedures but may complicate procedures undertaken for rupture. Acute kidney injury is more likely if there is preoperative renal impairment or considerable intraoperative blood loss.
    • Neurological complications include sexual dysfunction and spinal cord ischaemia.

Explanation:

Option A and D: Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm is a surgical emergency; it should be suspected in a patient with the triad of severe abdominal and/or back pain, hypotension and a pulsatile abdominal mass. If there is doubt about the presence of an aneurysm an ultrasonography scan may help but this cannot diagnose rupture. CT scanning should be used to establish the diagnosis and to confirm a rupture and whether an EVAR is possible: EVAR should be considered as the first-line option for all anatomically suitable ruptured aortic aneurysms.

Option B: Good venous access is needed for infusion of saline or volume-expanding fluids, but the systolic blood pressure should not be raised any more than is necessary to maintain consciousness and permit cardiac perfusion (<100 mmHg).

Option C: aneurysm is opened longitudinally in elective surgery

Key points:EVAR should be considered as the first-line option for all anatomically suitable ruptured aortic aneurysms.

questions.text: 70 year female presents with the following condition Which of the following is the Gold standard treatment?
questions.solution:
Option A :Phlebectomy

  • This may be performed following treatment of junctional incompetence and axial vein reflux, or as a sole treatment under local anaesthetic in patients with isolated tributary incompetence, or possibly in very early axial reflux.

Option B :Endovenous glue

  • The non-tumescent technique is the endoluminal application of cyanoacrylate adhesive. This involves a treatment catheter placed within the vein lumen. A handle is used to infiltrate the adhesive in 0.1-mL applications via the catheter. The vein is then compressed, sealing the lumen closed.

Option C: Saphenofemoral ligation and great saphenous stripping

An oblique groin incision is made at the level of, and lateral to, the pubic tubercle, ideally above the groin crease. The GSV is identified and dissected to the SFJ, which should be clearly established before the vein is divided to avoid disastrous inadvertent transection of the superficial femoral vein. A flush SFJ ligation is then performed and the GSV retrogradely stripped to around the knee.

D. Endovenous Thermal Ablation: Correct. Endovenous thermal ablation (using radiofrequency or laser energy) is currently considered the gold standard for the treatment of varicose veins. It is a minimally invasive procedure that results in fewer complications, quicker recovery, and better long-term outcomes compared to traditional surgery.

Endothermal ablation

  • Endothermal ablation technologies replaced surgical ligation and stripping as the gold standardtreatment once randomised trials demonstrated that they were marginally safer, have extremely high technical efficacy, offer superior quality of life post procedure (with a rapid recovery) and equivalent improvements in quality of life in the longer term.
  • The techniques are cost-effectiveas they can be performed as an outpatient under local anaesthetic. The basic concept is that a treatment device is inserted into the incompetent axial vein percutaneously. The vein is surrounded by a tumescent local anaesthetic solution. This compresses the vein onto the treatment device, emptying it of blood.
  • It also hydro-dissects tissues such as nerves away from the zone of injury.
  • Finally, it acts as a heat sink, mopping up excess thermal energy to prevent remote damage. The treatment device then produces thermal energy that destroys the structure of the vein, resulting in permanent occlusion.
  • Two broad technologiesexist: laser ablation and radiofrequency ablation (RFA).

Laser ablation Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)

  • utilises a small flexible glass fibre that is inserted into the vein. Laser energy (typically at a wavelength of 1470 nm) is transmitted down the fibre and is absorbed at the point of treatment at the end of the fibre. Absorption of this radiation results in a vigorous generation of thermal energy.

Radiofrequency ablation

  • RFA uses the same treatment principles, but an electromagnetic current is used to create the thermal energy. A range of different devices have been created but the most popular, which has the most supportive evidence, is the ClosureFast™ device (Medtronic) .This device has a wire coil on the end of a treatment catheter.
  • The generator passes an electrical current through the coil until the surrounding temperature reaches 120°C. This is then maintained for a treatment cycle of 20 seconds. The coil is then withdrawn for a set length and another treatment cycle is commenced. Coils of 3 cm and 7 cm are produced, with the latter increasing the speed of treatment, while still being suitable for most anatomies.

Key points : Endovenous thermal ablation, including radiofrequency or laser therapy, has become the preferred treatment for varicose veins due to its minimally invasive nature and excellent efficacy.

questions.text: 88 years old Mohandas presented with a history of intermittent claudication. Initially, he used to walk for 700 meters without pain, but now after walking for 100 meters, he develops the pain. The pain was exaggerated by lying down and improved by hanging the legs by the side of the bed. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Intermittent claudication

  • Intermittent claudication occurs as a result of anaerobic muscle metabolism and is classically described as debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the muscles that is:
  • brought on by walking;
  • not present on taking the first step (unlike osteoarthritis)
  • relieved by rest in both the standing and sitting positions, usually within 5 minutes (unlike nerve compression from a lumbar intervertebral disc prolapse or osteoarthritis of the spine or spinal stenosis, which are typically relieved only when resting in the sitting position for longer than 5 minutes).
  • The distance that a patient is able to walk without stopping varies (claudication distance) only slightly from day to day.

Rest pain

  • As disease progressionoccurs the claudication distance decreases and perfusion to the leg may be so severely compromised that anaerobic respiration occurs even at rest, typically affecting the foot and/or calf.
  • The pain is exacerbated by lying downor elevation of the foot because of the loss of gravitational effects on the perfusion pressure in the foot.
  • The patient characteristically describes pain that is worse at night and may be lessened by hanging the foot out of bed or by sleeping in a chair (effects of gravity restored). Even the pressure of bedclothes on the foot may exacerbate the pain.

Explanation:

Option A. Neurogenic claudication: Incorrect. Neurogenic claudication is caused by spinal stenosis and typically improves with flexing the spine (e.g., sitting or leaning forward). The pain is usually in the buttocks or legs and is not improved by hanging the legs down.

Option B. Sciatic pain: Incorrect. Sciatic pain is nerve-related, radiating down the leg and typically worsened by sitting or bending forward. It does not improve with leg elevation or hanging the leg down.

Option C. Rest pain: Correct. Rest pain is a symptom of advanced peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The pain typically occurs at rest, especially at night, and is relieved by dangling the legs off the bed or walking due to the increased blood flow. The patient's history of worsening claudication suggests PAD progression leading to rest pain.

Option D. None: Incorrect.

Key points :

  • In nerve compression from a lumbar intervertebral disc prolapse or osteoarthritis of the spine or spinal stenosis, in which pain is typically relieved only when resting in the sitting position for longer than 5 minutes.
  • Rest pain is a late sign of peripheral arterial disease, characterized by pain in the legs during rest, particularly at night. It is typically relieved by hanging the legs off the bed, allowing gravity to improve blood flow.

questions.text: 35 year old smoker more than 15 years with comment your diagnosis based on given image
questions.solution:
Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease)

  • An inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder affecting small and medium-sized arteries and veins in the arms and legs, often seen in young male smokers.
  • Symptoms:
    • Involvement of upper and lower extremities, Raynaud's phenomenon, and superficial or deep vein thrombophlebitis.
  • Cause: Strong association with cigarette smoking.
  • Treatment:
    • Complete abstinence from smoking.
    • No specific treatment; management includes standard care for arterial occlusions, but amputation may be necessary.

Explanation:

Option A: Buerger disease. This is characterized by occlusive disease of small and medium-sized limb arteries, thrombophlebitis of superficial or deep veins, and Raynaud's syndrome; it usually occurs in young male smokers.

Option B : Atherosclerosis: old age with a history of intermittent claudication leads to the diagnosis of atherosclerosis.

Option C :Giant cell arteritis will lead to headache and pulseless arteries in scalp .

Option D: Raynaud disease: This idiopathic condition usually occurs in young women and affects the hands more than the feet. There is abnormal sensitivity in the arteriolar response to cold. These vessels constrict and the digits (usually the fingers) turn white and become incapable of fine movements.

Key points :Buerger disease is characterized by occlusive disease of small and medium-sized limb arteries, thrombophlebitis of superficial or deep veins and Raynaud's syndrome; it usually occurs in young male smokers.

choices.text: The most commonly used is calcium tetradecyl sulphate.
It causes non inflammatory obliteration of veins
Blood deactivates the action of the sclerosing agent

questions.text: 40 year female presents with reticular veins ,undergoes following therapy . identify true statement regarding procedure.
questions.solution:
Sclerotherapy

  • Ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy Sclerotherapy involves the injection of a sclerosing agent directly into the superficial veins.
  • The most commonly used is sodium tetradecyl sulphate.
  • The direct contact with detergent causes cellular death and initiates an inflammatory response, aiming to result in thrombosis, fibrosis and obliteration (sclerosis).
  • Blood deactivates the action of the sclerosing agent and the doses administered need to be limited to avoid adverse effects, causing a trade-off between poor efficacy and safety. This led to the development of ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy (UGFS).
  • The use of foam increases the effective volume of the agent, maximising endothelial contact and displacing any blood that deactivates it.
  • The most widely used method is that of Tessari; this utilises two syringes connected using a three-way tap. A 1:3 or 1:4 ratio mixture of sclerosant and air is drawn into one syringe, and is then oscillated vigorously between the two syringes about 10 or 20 times . The foam produced in this way is stable for about 2 minutes so it should be injected as soon as it has been made. The leg is then elevated to empty the veins of blood, and injection of foam commences first with superficial varicosities and ends with injection of the GSV or SSV.

questions.text: Stemmer's sign comes under which grade of lymphoedema?
questions.solution:
Stemmer's sign seen in Lymphedema

Skin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched due to Subcutaneous Fibrosis

LYMPHOEDEMA BRUNNER GRADE

  • Classification:
    • Primary Lymphedema: No known cause; classified by age of onset:
      • Congenital Lymphedema: Onset before age 1; familial form is Milroy disease.
      • Lymphedema Praecox: Onset between ages 1-35; familial form is Meige disease (around puberty).
      • Lymphedema Tarda: Onset after age 35.Lymphedema Praecox is the most common form of primary lymphedema.
    • Secondary Lymphedema: Caused by an identifiable disease or condition.
      • Worldwide cause: Filariasis from Wuchereria bancrofti.
      • Developed countries: Due to surgery, radiation therapy, tumor invasion, or trauma

Option A. Grade 1: Incorrect. Grade 1 lymphedema, or reversible lymphedema, typically presents with swelling that reduces with elevation and no significant skin changes.

Option B. Grade 2: Incorrect. Grade 2 lymphedema, also known as spontaneously irreversible lymphedema, presents with more persistent swelling and harder skin, but Stemmer's sign is usually positive.

Option C. Grade 3: Correct. In Grade 3 lymphedema, also known as lymphostatic elephantiasis, there is significant thickening of the skin.

Option D. Grade 4: Incorrect. Grade 4 is an uncommon classification and not typically used in standard clinical practice.

questions.text: Not part of Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome
questions.solution:
• Klippel-Trénaunay syndrome is a combined anomaly of a cutaneous naevus, persistent vestigial veins with varicose veins and soft-tissue and bone hypertrophy. only option (B) IS WRONG.

Klippel-Trénaunay syndrome This is a combined anomaly of a cutaneous naevus, persistent vestigial veins with varicose veins and soft-tissue and bone hypertrophy. The condition is a mesodermal abnormality that is not familial.

  • Segments of the deep veins are hypoplastic or aplastic and there may be an associated obstruction of the lymphatics.
  • The condition must be distinguished from the Parkes-Weber syndrome, in which there are multiple arteriovenous fistula causing venous hypertension, ulceration and high-output cardiac failure.
  • Virtually all patients with Klippel-Trénaunay syndrome should be treated conservatively with compression hosiery; however, some will benefit from laser ablation of the naevus, stapling of the bones to avoid leg length discrepancy and occasional removal of large superficial varicose veins.
  • LMWH should be given to all patients having surgery as this syndrome is associated with an increased risk of VTE.

choices.text: Treatment includes vitamin k for 3 months
Treatment with warfarin therapy for 3 months
Phlegmasia alba dolens, the thrombosis involves only major deep venous channels

questions.text: 78 years old Nayana ben, presents with painful swollen leg. diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis. Which of the following is wrong statement for this case?
questions.solution:
SIGNS RELATED TO VENOUS THROMBOSIS AND TREATMENT

  • In Phlegmasia alba dolens, the thrombosis involves only major deep venous channels of the extremity, thus sparing collateral veins. The venous drainage is decreased but still present; the lack of cyanosis differentiates this entity from phlegmesia cerulea Dolens. Phlegmasia alba dolens also known as "milk leg".
  • In Phlegmasia cerulea dolens, the thrombosis extends to collateral veins, resulting in severe venous congestion with massive fluid sequestration and more significant edema. Both phlegmasia cerulea dolens and phlegmasia alba dolens are complicated by venous gangrene.

Explanation:

Option A. Treatment includes vitamin K for 3 months: Incorrect. Vitamin K is not a treatment for deep vein thrombosis (DVT); it is used as an antidote to reverse the effects of warfarin in cases of excessive anticoagulation or bleeding. DVT treatment involves anticoagulation, typically with warfarin or newer anticoagulants, not vitamin K.

Option B. Treatment with warfarin therapy for 3 months: Correct. Standard treatment for DVT includes anticoagulation therapy, often starting with heparin and transitioning to warfarin for 3 to 6 months, depending on the risk of recurrence.

Option C. Phlegmasia alba dolens, the thrombosis involves only major deep venous channels: Correct. Phlegmasia alba dolens is a severe form of DVT where thrombosis involves major deep veins, leading to significant venous congestion, but not complete venous obstruction.

Option D. Homan's sign will be positive: Correct. Homan's sign is calf pain elicited by dorsiflexion of the foot, and while it is a classic clinical sign of DVT, it is neither sensitive nor specific for diagnosis.

Key points:

Treatment of DVT involves anticoagulants like warfarin, not vitamin K. Phlegmasia alba dolens involves major deep veins, and Homan's sign may be present but is not a reliable diagnostic indicator.

questions.text: 28 years old Neetaben, while washing clothes in cold water notices colour changes of her hands from white to red. Which of the following drugs is best suited for this patient?
questions.solution:
Raynaud's Disease:

  • Population: Common in young women.
  • Affected Areas: Primarily affects hands, sometimes feet.
  • Pathophysiology: Abnormal arteriolar sensitivity to cold leads to vasoconstriction.
  • Symptoms:
    1. Blanching (white) due to arteriolar constriction.
    2. Cyanosis (blue) due to capillary dilation and deoxygenated blood.
    3. Redness (engorgement) as oxygenated blood returns.
  • Complications: Superficial necrosis is rare.
  • Treatment:
    • Protection from cold, calcium antagonists (e.g., nifedipine).
    • Avoid infection of pulp/nail beds, electrically heated gloves in winter.

Raynaud's Syndrome:

  • Etiology: Secondary to collagen diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis) or vibration exposure (e.g., "vibration white finger").
  • Symptoms: Similar to Raynaud's disease but more severe, with potential for necrosis and multiple amputations.
  • Treatment: Focus on underlying disease, steroids, vasospastic antagonists, and conservative measures. Sympathectomy is not recommended.

Explanation:

Option A. ACE inhibitors: Incorrect. ACE inhibitors are primarily used for hypertension and heart failure but are not the first-line treatment for Raynaud's disease.

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: Correct. Calcium channel blockers, such as nifedipine, are the most effective drugs for managing Raynaud's disease. They help by dilating blood vessels and reducing the vasospastic response triggered by cold exposure.

Option C. Thiazides: Incorrect. Thiazides are diuretics used for managing hypertension, but they are not effective in treating Raynaud's disease.

Option D. Alpha blockers: Incorrect. Alpha blockers may have some vasodilatory effects, but they are not as effective as calcium channel blockers in the management of Raynaud's disease.

Key points :The primary difference between Raynaud's disease and Raynaud's syndrome is that the latter is secondary to systemic diseases and has a more aggressive course, often leading to necrosis and amputations.

questions.text: Patient with peripheral vascular disease comes for follow up for non healing ulcer over foot. An absolute pressure from the hallux of less than.........indicates severe ischemia that is likely to prevent healing of ulceration. ABPI of......... associated with severe PVD.
questions.solution:
ABPI AND TOE PRESSURE

  • ankle-brachial pressure index (ABI), which is the ratio of the systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the ipsilateral arm.
  • The highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial or peroneal artery serves as the numerator, with the highest brachial systolic pressure being the denominator.
  • The normal resting ABI is 0.9-1.4; values below 0.9 indicate a hemodynamically significant arterial lesion; a value less than 0.4 suggests CLTI. Values are merely a guide and normal values may be present with intermittent claudication. Retesting after exercise to the onset of pain can be useful; a drop in the resting ABI of >20% after exercise is indicative of flow-limiting arterial disease. Artificially high ABI readings (>1.4) can be caused by media sclerosis and calcification of the arterial wall, causing vessel incompressibility and a falsely elevated ABI; this pattern of disease typically occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus (DM).
  • Toe (digital) arteries are rarely affected by sclerosis and a toe-brachial pressure index (TBI) in combination with ABI is advocated as a more reliable diagnostic tool for the detection of significant large-vessel steno-occlusive disease in patients with DM.
  • A TBI less than 0.6 suggests a significant arterial lesion that may have been overlooked if ABI was used in isolation

questions.text: 30 year nayan with a history of massive RTA developed dyspnea and petechial rashes after 3 days following femur fracture. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES)

  • Key Features: Characterized by respiratory distress, altered mental status, and petechiae, typically seen after long bone or pelvic fractures.
  • Pathophysiology: Marrow fat enters the pulmonary circulation, leading to inflammatory and coagulative responses.
  • Onset: Symptoms occur hours to days after injury.
  • Treatment: Primarily supportive care; corticosteroids may reduce the risk of FES.
  • FES may represent a subset of ARDS. ARDS is a pulmonary failure state defined as a Pao2/Fio2 ratio lower than 200 regardless of the level of positive end-expiratory pressure, a pulmonary artery occlusion pressure of 18 mm Hg or less, or bilateral diffuse infiltrates on chest radiographs in the absence of congestive heart failure.
  • Prevention: Early fracture fixation (<24 hours) reduces the incidence of FES and ARDS.

Air Embolism:

  • Key Features: Can occur after air enters the venous circulation, particularly during head, neck, or gynecological procedures.
  • Pathophysiology: Air forms an obstruction in the pulmonary artery, leading to acute right heart failure.
  • Treatment: Trendelenburg position, placing the patient on their left side, and in severe cases, aspiration of air via a needle in the heart.
  • Both conditions require urgent management and vary in their causes and outcomes.

Explanation:

Option A. Massive haemorrhage: Incorrect. Massive hemorrhage typically presents with signs of hypovolemic shock such as hypotension, tachycardia, and pallor, rather than petechial rashes and respiratory symptoms after a few days of injury.

Option B. Fat embolism: Correct. Fat embolism syndrome (FES) is common after long bone fractures, particularly the femur. It typically presents 1-3 days post-trauma with a classic triad of dyspnea, neurological impairment, and petechial rash. Fat globules enter the bloodstream and lodge in the pulmonary and systemic circulation, leading to respiratory and systemic symptoms.

Option C. Thromboembolism: Incorrect. While thromboembolism could cause respiratory symptoms, it does not typically present with petechial rashes, and it is less associated with long bone fractures compared to fat embolism.

Option D. Air embolism: Incorrect. Air embolism typically results from trauma to veins or surgical procedures, and would not be the most likely cause after a long bone fracture.

Key Points:

Fat embolism triad: Dyspnea, altered mental status, petechial rash

questions.text: Patients with DVT had pitting edema, tachycardia, and a history of rectal cancer, patient later develops hemoptysis. According to modified Well's scoring for pulmonary embolism,the score would be:
questions.solution:
Here score will be 3+1.5 +1+1 =6.5.

  • All other options are wrong.

choices.text: Orthopedic wool, cotton crepe, cohesive bandage, elastic bandage
Orthopedic wool, cotton crepe, elastic bandage, cohesive bandage
Cohesive bandage, Elastic bandage, cotton crepe, orthopedic wool
Elastic bandage, cohesive bandage, orthopedic wool, cotton crepe

questions.text: As intern doctor on surgical ward, you are asked to do dressing for venous ulcer, The layers from inside to outside are.......
questions.solution:
The most clinical and cost-effective compression regimes are two-layer compression hosiery or four-layer compression bandaging. The latter includes:

  • Orthopedic wool: distributes the pressure and reduces undue pressure on sensitive areas susceptible to pressure damage. Also helps to absorb excess exudate that escapes the primary dressing.
  • Cotton crepe: smooths the wool and holds it in place.
  • Elastic bandage: first compressive layer, contributes about one-third of the interface pressure.
  • Cohesive bandage: second compressive layer, increases stiffness and adds approximately two-thirds of the interface pressure.
  • The ideal interface pressure in pure venous ulceration is 35 40 mmHg.

Key points:

  • Venous Ulcers usually lie just proximal to the medial or lateral malleolus.
  • Venous ulcers are accompanied by Lipodermatosclerosis and Hemosiderosis. If these features are not present then the ulcer is probably not of venous origin.

questions.text: While doing flush ligation in case of varicose veins, GSV tributaries may be encountered close to the SFJ. All of the following tributaries given below are true except ........
questions.solution:
GSV tributaries

The anatomy is often variable but six GSV tributaries may be encountered close to the SFJ:

  • Laterally:
    • superficial inferior epigastric vein;
    • superficial circumflex iliac vein.
  • Medially:
    • superficial external pudendal vein;
    • deep external pudendal vein.
  • Distally:
    • anterior accessory of the great saphenous vein;
    • posteromedial thigh vein.

Key points:

  • During varicose vein surgery near the saphenofemoral junction, lateral tributaries include the superficial circumflex iliac vein, while medial tributaries include the superficial and deep external pudendal veins.

Explanation :

Option A. Deep inferior epigastric vein - laterally: Incorrect. The deep inferior epigastric vein does not drain laterally to the GSV. It is not typically encountered during flush ligation of the GSV at the SFJ as it drains directly into the external iliac vein.

Option B. Superficial circumflex iliac vein - laterally: Correct. This vein is a lateral tributary of the GSV close to the SFJ.

Option C. Superficial external pudendal vein - medially: Correct. This tributary drains medially and is often encountered during GSV ligation.

Option D. Deep external pudendal vein - medially: Correct. Like the superficial external pudendal vein, this vein also drains medially and is encountered during surgery near the SFJ.

questions.text: Akanksha, known for Atrial fibrillation developed sudden arterial occlusive disease, leads to pain in left leg with loss of DPA pulse Which of the following has the poorest prognosis?
questions.solution:
Sudden Arterial Occlusion

Embolic Occlusion:

  • Key Features: Embolus lodges in a vessel causing acute occlusion, often from a thrombus that has detached from the heart or a proximal vessel (e.g., in atrial fibrillation, myocardial infarction, or infective endocarditis).
  • Symptoms: Known as the five Ps of acute limb ischemia: pain, pallor, paraesthesia, paralysis, pulselessness.
  • Management: Differentiating between embolic occlusion and thrombosis on atherosclerotic plaque is essential, as embolism requires urgent intervention due to the lack of collateral circulation.
  • Motor deficit or paralysis shows irreversible changes .

Explanation:

Option A. Pain: Incorrect. Pain is an early symptom of arterial occlusion, but it does not indicate the most severe damage.

Option B. Pallor: Incorrect. Pallor indicates reduced blood flow but is not necessarily associated with a poor prognosis if treated promptly.

Option C. Pulselessness: Incorrect. While the absence of a pulse is concerning, it can often be reversed with timely intervention.

Option D. Paralysis: Correct. Paralysis suggests that ischemia has progressed to the point of muscle and nerve damage, which is often irreversible and associated with the poorest prognosis.

Key points:

  • In acute arterial occlusion, paralysis is the worst prognostic sign as it indicates irreversible muscle and nerve damage due to prolonged ischemia.
